utterances: I don't think that Dean Barkley can surge to win.
But I think that he can surge to 15 percent, maybe 18 percent, depending on how negative the race is, depending on the mood in the country.
Ventura was such a powerful personality, powerful negative or positive, depending on how you viewed him.
Dean Barkley, who I know well and who I like, is a wonderful guy but he's not like that.
He's a more - much conventional personality.
He's not going to capture the imagination, in my judgment, of swing voters, young voters, the kind of people that surge through...
He wasn't the fourth guy in ""Predator""?
(Soundbite of laughter)
He didn't campaign with a bow and his head.
I mean, obviously - I think what did up Jesse Ventura was that late-minute debate where he really excited everybody, and that's what a lot of the Ralph Nader people complain about.
They say that if they had an opportunity to, you know, debate.
That's right, and the constituency that turned out for him was young people, who you normally think aren't going to vote no matter what they say.
They turned out in droves for Jesse Ventura.
But he turned out to be an extremely unpopular governor in the long run.
Yeah.
He was - you know, it's interesting.
He wasn't a bad governor.
He appointed a bipartisan group, very good commissioners who ran the state in a pretty much non-partisan way.

He became very unpopular because of things he said, which in many cases had nothing to do with his being governor because - for instance, he dished organized religions, he said it was for people with weak minds.
Well, you know, Minnesota's a state where you've got a very organized Lutheran church, and a big Catholic church.
I mean, organized churches, a whole string of private colleges that are church-based in Minnesota.
A whole thing - but that had nothing to do with being governor of Minnesota.
But it's things like that, as opposed to governing the state, that made him unpopular.
Anna Greenberg, there a couple of other interesting and surprising Senate contests.
One, who expected North Carolina to be a contest?
Absolutely.

I think, you know, Elizabeth Dole has real issues, certainly real issues about around fundraising, which, when she was the head of the Republican Senate Campaign Committee, she didn't do a terribly good job and she's not done a terribly good job on her own.
And she's got some personal issues, but there's a lot places you wouldn't imagine.
You know, Alaska, obviously, Stevens has big, big, big problems but Alaska is not generally placed....
He's got big problems in Washington, D.C.
First, he's sitting on trial.
Yes, he's got problems in both places, but generally not a state you think of as competitive.
And then you have other places, like Kentucky, there have been two public polls that have showed the race tied.
Now I don't know if that's true or not but if, you know, McConnell's the minority leader in the Senate, and it's sort of like, sort of Tom Folley losing.
It's - so there's - I think there's a real wave and it is possible that Democrats can pick upwards of eight Senate seats, if you look at where the races are right now.
And get close to the 60 votes that they're hoping to get, you know.
Ken?
Yeah, that's what so remarkable about it.
I mean, we know that, for example, the open seat of Virginia was going to go Democratic.
We know that Colorado and New Mexico with the two Yudall(ph) cousins are running two Democrats, most likely pick up for the Democrats.
But Gordon Smith was not supposed to be in trouble in Oregon.
Elizabeth Dole, the Democratic challenger there.
Kay Hagan was supposed to be a very non-exciting candidate, unimpressive candidate, and yet Elizabeth Dole has not shown up from any campaign rallies.
She's not been in the state that much, and the polls show - many polls show Hagen ahead, which would be a real shocker.
Mary Landrieu of Louisiana thought to be one Democrat who might be vulnerable this year?
She had double-digit lead over John Kennedy, the Democrat turned Republican for her state Treasurer.
She was supposed to be the only Democrat of any kind of problems.
And not because of anything she did wrong but because of demographics.
She can't use that old Lloyd Benson(ph) line?
No, no. I knew John Kennedy by...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Although that's still - but that's still a competitive - I agree with you.
The Republicans lost ground there because of the hurricane.
It helped the incumbent.
She was able to be the incumbent, but that is still a competitive race.
It's kind of (unintelligible).
One of few states this year that's turning Republican.
John McCain has a 25-point lead.
That's still definitely a competitive state.
Saxby Chamblise in Georgia, latest poll shows him up only two points.
That would be a stunner.
Look, the economic problems you face drag down Republican numbers across the board, just sort of restating what I said earlier, and it makes a lot of people look vulnerable.
Anna says maybe there's a tide coming.
It's going to sweep out all sorts of people.
When you have a tide like that, a Watergate tide or a 1994 Republican tide, you ride.
A lot of people lose that you don't think is going to lose.
I had to say it.
I'm not at all convinced that's where we are in this race at this point.
But states like Mississippi, where there also is - you know, looking like a potentially competitive race and Georgia have large African-American populations.
And turnout among African-Americans is not just going to be high, there are going to be a lot of African-Americans registered and voting who don't normally participate.
So it is possible that a tide plus record African-American turnout in some of these Southern States could, you know, it could win some seats.
Yeah, but it has bounced back and forth, as been said before.
But anyway, let's see if we get some more callers on the line.
Let's go to Katherine(ph), Katherine with us from Jacksonville in Florida.
Hi.
Hi, Katherine.
Ken, as always, thanks very much for your time today.
You're listening to Talk of the Nation coming to you from NPR News.
Hi, I am just (unintelligible) on.
I'm in a swing state, obviously, and I've been receiving a lot of mail from Obama, and my Dad made a comment because he's not receiving anything.
He's a registered Republican, me and my Mom were registered Democrats.
And I thought it was very interesting that it's all coming to us, and you know, obviously, I believe we're going to vote for Obama.

But he's not giving anything, and I was wondering how they target who they want to vote for them in a place where - you know, I would think that he would want my Dad's vote more than he would be begging for mine, you know?
The Republican campaign has given great credit for knowing who their voters are and targeting them.
Yeah.
I can't offer an explanation.
That part of the campaign is supposed to be both going very well, and the caller's right, her Dad should be getting a lot of mail.
Thanks very much.
He's not getting anything.
OK, thank you though.
Thanks for the call, Katherine.
Appreciate it.
Let's see if we can go now to - this is - if I could find the right button - this is Jim, Jim with us from Spencer in Iowa.
Yes, hi.
Hi, go ahead, Jim.
I've actually been to Spencer Island.
Yeah, I think Bush is pulling this wheezing gas guzzler up to the gas pump course at the end of this term of his like the family vacation car that didn't make it to Wally World in time, but...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well - go ahead.
Go ahead.
We'll skip the (unintelligible) jokes.
Go ahead.
Yeah, anyway, we still have the dead relative on top.
I was in the state capital the other day, and a conservative representative came up to a party organizer for the Democrats who had his cane in hand and said, I want you to beat McCain.

And that was the first time I think I've ever heard somebody from that side of the island encourage us to get a man like McCain in there, and I hope that he can get this thing pushed up a lot with, you know, a little better mileage than we've had from Wall Street in the past.
The only thing that might be straining more is the metaphor here.
(Soundbite of laughter)
But Jim, thanks very much for the call.
Appreciate it.
Sure.
Bye-bye.
Here's an email for me.
Mr. Conan, as a proud Canuck, I say, tish, tish regarding your comment that some would consider the appointment to ambassador of Canada being equivalent to defeat.
Many of my dearest American friends tell me they think you're moving north to God's country if the November elections swings right again.
What do you think of that, eh?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's see if we get one - we've got just a couple of minutes with you and will reconvene before Election Day.
But I wanted to ask you.
Anna, we've got three more debates, one vice presidential, two presidential.
Other than that, what could change the dynamic of this race?
We've seen John McCain go for the Hail Mary pass a couple of times now.
I honestly am having a hard time thinking of what could change the dynamic.
Hopefully, you know, Vin can probably come up with something.
I mean, it seems to me that where we are economically is where we are.
I can't imagine suddenly we're going to have a miraculous economic recovery and people are going to feel more comfortable with John McCain on economics.
So I think that piece is sort of, well, it's well set.
Potentially, something could happen internationally and people might feel, you know, more comfortable with John McCain because he's got - has experience in that area.
But it's hard to - again, I see underlying trends that are all going in the wrong direction for John McCain.
And it's right now hard for me to imagine what could push it in another direction.
Game changes, Vin Weber?
Well, I think Anna has got it about right.
The international scene is where you have to look for something to help McCain.
And it's not so much that everybody's anxieties about the economy would go away but that they would - there would be room for other news.
And if we haven't been in the middle of this financial crisis, the biggest story last couple of weeks would have been the bombing of the Marriott Hotel in Islamabad.
